Notes: Sharing copies of Corinne

Notes: Sharing copies of Corinne

Author: John Quincy Adams
Keywords: A Treatise upon the Influence of the Passions upon the Happiness of individuals and of Nations, French
Notes: John Quincy Adams tells Abigal he will be sending some French texts "and among them a very curious work" of Staël's: A Treatise upon the Influence of the Passions upon the Happiness of individuals and of Nations.

Author: Gouverneur Morris
Notes: Describing salons held at Staël's house to discuss arguments

Author: Louisa Catherine Adams
Keywords: book, A Treatise upon the Influence of the Passions upon the Happiness of individuals and of Nations
Notes: Louisa Catherine Adams tells John Quincy that, per John Quincy's recommendation, she intends to read A Treatise upon the Influence of the Passions upon the Happiness of individuals and of Nations, but she would prefer to learn philosophy from him.

Author: Gouverneur Morris
Keywords: Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord, Narbonne, revolution, king, Antoine Claude Nicolas Valdec de Lessart
Notes: Discussing rumors around Staël's affair with Narbonne and Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord. Morris describes a "coldness" between Narbone and Talleyrand- Périgord that arose from these rumors. He says that Talleyrand- Périgord tried to get Narbonne appointed to foriegn affairs, but the king appointed Lessart "because of the great indiscretion" of de Staël.

Author: Joseph Milligan
Notes: ACCOUNTS (not correspondence)

Author: Peter Roche
Notes: ACCOUNTS (not correspondence)

Author: Joseph Milligan
Notes: ACCOUNTS (not correspondence)

Author: Louisa Catherine Adams
Notes: Louisa Catherine Adams writes John Quincy Adams after reading Delphine. She reads Staël as endorsing divorce and says that this text is "calculated to destroy every moral principal to destroy every tie which binds society together."

Author: John Quincy Adams
Notes: John Quincy Adams responds to Louisa Catherine Adams. He says he has not read Delphine yet, but he will if he can get a copy. He reassures Louisa that he does not agree with Staël's endorsement of divorce. He thinks her opinions on divorce come from her "having sacrificed all deceny as well as all virtue in her own conduct" and from the French "who could not promise to love any thing for life." He signs the letter ensuring Louisa of his devotion to marriage: "I am my dearest Louisa, whatever Madame de Staal, or the french haters may say, for life, most affectionately yours."

Author: Lefray De Chaumont
Notes: Chaumont sends Jefferson, from Staël, a letter and a copy of her book.

Author: Thomas Jefferson
Notes: Extends invitation to Madame De Stael's son Auguste to come to the U.S., "resistance becomes morality"

Author: John Payne Todd
Notes: John Payne Todd sends James Madison some article found in the Paris journals which is rumored to have been written by Staël. Todd says that Staël "requests [him] to make known to [James Madison] her high respect"

Author: George Ticknor
Notes: Ticknor talks about the impact of Staël's On Germany on the U.S understanding of German literature.

Author: Stael
Keywords: Corinne, Napoleon, French revolution, French empire, England's resistance of Napoleon, United States involvement in Europe
Notes: Explaining situation in Europe and England's status as the last resistance to Napoleon's despotism

Author: John Speyer
Notes: Sending a letter written by Staël while she is in Sotckholm.

Author: William Short
Keywords: Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution, French, revolution
Notes: Short tells Jefferson about the books he recieved from France including Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution. He says, about the text, "It is certainly the best of all her works, & I think, the best work on the French revolution."

Notes: Sharing copies of Corinne

Author: Abigal Adams
Notes: Announcing Baron de Staël is going to Jacques Necker's daughter, Germaine.

Author: John Adams
Notes: John tells Abigal that Staël has published Reflections on Peace which has been answered by Francis D'Invernois' Reflections on War.

Author: Thomas Jefferson
Keywords: Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution
Notes: Jefferson sends a box of books to Milton to send to Milligan. This box includes Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution.

Author: William Short
Keywords: revolution, likely Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution
Notes: Short asks Jefferson if he has seen Staël's latest work (perhaps Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution). Short describes it as "the most faithful picture of the great personages of the Revolution that I have seen."

Author: Thomas Jefferson
Keywords: likely Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution
Notes: Jefferson responds to Short and confirms he has recieved a copy of (likely) Considerations on the Principal Events of the French Revolution from Staël's son and son in law. He says "it is indeed a most precious & superlative work.”
